chapter.title: The Fundamental Theorem of Complex Analysis and its immediate consequences
chapter.introduction: In this chapter we are going to illustrate how strong is the property of being complex-differentiable for a map \Bbb R^2\to\Bbb R^2. In comparison with differentiability of maps \Bbb R\to\Bbb R, the complex counterpart turns out to be extremely more rigid. We will ultimately show that a map that is complex-differentiable over an open set is actually analytic on that very set.

section.title: Some relevant spaces of differentiable maps
section.definition: Given two open sets V\subset K^n and W\subset K^m, where K is either \Bbb R or \Bbb C, we denote by D^k(V,W) the space of all maps V\to W that are differentiable k times at every point of V and by C^k(V,W) the subset of D^k(V,W) of those maps whose k-th derivative is continuous. When m=1, maps are just called functions and often the second space is omitted in the notation: D^k(V) and C^k(V) are the spaces of functions V\to K.
section.p:
Since differentiabilty implies continuity, clearly C^{k-1}(V)\supset D^k(V). More generally,
C^0(V)\supset D^1(V)\supset C^1(V)\supset D^2(V)\supset C^2(V)\supset\dots\supset D^k(V)\supset C^k(V)\supset\dots
while D^\infty(V)=C^\infty(V).
In the real case, these spaces are all distinct. [PUT EXAMPLES!!!]

section.title: The Fundamental Theorem
section.p: We shall prove below the fundamental theorem by showing the following chain of implications: 2\implies3\implies4\implies5\implies6\implies7\implies8\implies1\implies9\implies10\implies2.
section.proof:
Since f(z) is C^1 as a complex function, then its components u(x,y),v(x,y) are C^1 as real functions. The existence of \lim_{h\to0}\frac{f(z_0+h)-f(z_0)}{h}, z_0=x_0+iy_0, implies that this limit does not depend on how h approaches 0.
Take first h=\varepsilon. Then
\lim_{h\to0}\frac{f(z+h)-f(z)}{h} =
= \lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{u(x_0+\varepsilon,y_0)-u(x_0,y_0)}{\varepsilon}+i\frac{v(x_0+\varepsilon,y_0)-v(x_0,y_0)}{\varepsilon} =
=u_x(x_0,y_0) + i v_x(x_0,y_0),
Now take h=i\varepsilon. Then
\lim_{h\to0}\frac{f(z+h)-f(z)}{h}=
= \lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\frac{u(x_0,y_0+\varepsilon)-u(x_0,y_0)}{i\varepsilon}+i\frac{v(x_0,y_0+\varepsilon)-v(x_0,y_0)}{i\varepsilon} =
= -iu_y(x_0,y_0) + v_y(x_0,y_0).
By comparing these two expressions we get the Cauchy-Riemann equations.

df=f_z dz + f_{\bar z} d\bar z = (u_x+iv_x)dx+i(u_y+iv_y)dy, so
f_{\bar z} = \frac{1}{2}\left[(u_x-v_y)+i(v_x+u_y)\right] = 0.
Since dz\wedge dz, d(fdz)=(f_z dz + f_{\bar z} d\bar z)\wedge dz = f_{\bar z}d\bar z\wedge dz = 0.

Since d(fdz)=0 and \frac{1}{z-z_0} is holomorphic (where defined), also also d\left(\frac{f(z)}{z-z_0}dz\right)=0. For r small enough, \frac{f(z)}{z-z_0} is holomorphic in |z-z_0|\lt r, z\neq z_0, so that
\int\limits_{C_z(r)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta-z_0}d\zeta - \int\limits_{C_z(\varepsilon)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta-z_0}d\zeta = \int\limits_{\varepsilon\lt|\zeta-z_0|\lt r}d\left(\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta-z_0}d\zeta\right)=0
for every \varepsilon\lt r. Since f is differentiable at z_0, on |z-z_0|=\varepsilon we have that f(\zeta)=f(z_0)+\varepsilon g(\zeta), with \lim_{\zeta\to z_0}g(\zeta)=0. Hence
\lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\int\limits_{C_z(\varepsilon)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta-z_0}d\zeta = \int\limits_{C_z(\varepsilon)}\frac{f(z_0)}{\zeta-z_0}d\zeta + \lim_{\varepsilon\to0}\varepsilon\int\limits_{C_z(\varepsilon)}\frac{g(\zeta)}{\zeta-z_0}d\zeta = 2\pi i f(z_0)
and the Cauchy integral formula follows.

proof.p: We can prove WLOG the theorem for z_0=0, so that \displaystyle f(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi i}\!\!\int\limits_{C_0(r)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta for |z| small enough. Notice that, since \zeta\in C_0(r), |z|\lt|\zeta| and so \frac{1}{\zeta-z} = \frac{1}{\zeta}\frac{1}{1-\frac{z}{\zeta}}=\frac{1}{\zeta}\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{z}{\zeta}\right)^n, which converges uniformly in \zeta over compacts.

Hence, for all z close enough to 0,
\displaystyle f(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi i}\!\!\int\limits_{C_0(r)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta = \frac{1}{2\pi i}\!\!\int\limits_{C_0(r)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta}\sum_{n=0}^\infty\left(\frac{z}{\zeta}\right)^nd\zeta = \sum_{n=0}^\infty\left[\frac{1}{2\pi i}\!\!\int\limits_{C_0(r)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta^{n+1}}d\zeta\right]\cdot z^n.

section.proof: Since f is C^\infty by hypothesis, fdz is closed and so it is locally exact, namely locally fdz=dF for some holomorphich map F. Since dF=F'dz, it follows that locally f=F'.
Suppose that, close to z_0\in\Omega, f=F' for some C^1 map F. Since we already proved that 2\implies6, F is C^\infty and so f is also C^\infty and, in particular, holomorphic.

The proof of this statement is due to Goursat [ADD CITATION]. It is a very noteworthy argument because it shows that, at least in dimension 2, the C^1 assumption on the regularity of the form in Stokes theorem can be weakened to D^1.
[ADD PROOF]

Since the integral of fdz is zero on every contractible loop, we can build a holomorphic antiderivative close to any point z_0\in\Omega by defining F(z)=\int_{z_0}^zf(z)dz, where the integral is taken over any piecewise-C^1 loop starting at z_0 and ending at z. This definition is well-posed because, close enough to any given point, all loops are contractible and so the value of F(z) does not depend on the path. Hence f is analytic.
Let \Gamma a piecewise-C^1 loop inside \Omega containing K in its interior. Notice that such loop can be easily built by introducing a grid in \Omega [ADD PICTURE!!]. Then, since f is, in particular, C^1, it follows from 2\implies6 that \displaystyle f(z) = \frac{1}{2\pi i}\!\!\int\limits_{C_0(r)}\frac{f(\zeta)}{\zeta-z}d\zeta for each z\in K.
This integral can be approximated uniformly by Riemann sums by choosing some finite number of points on \Gamma. Each summand is a rational function with a pole on \Gamma, so this way we can build a sequence of rational functions converging uniformly to f on K.
The fact that every rational function with a pole in some component of \overline{\Bbb C}\setminus K can be uniformly approximated in K by a sequence of rational functions having as pole a given point of that same component was proven in [ADD THIS THM IN THE POWER SERIES CHAPTER!!]
Since the convergence is uniform over compacts and every rational function is analytic, their limit is analytic and, in particolar, is C^1.
section.p: Before discussing the many important consequences of this theorem, several remarks are in order.

Cauchy's Theorem. Implication 1\implies9 is known as Cauchy Theorem. Cauchy's original proof, first published in 1825 and improved in 1846 , as well as Riemann's version published in 1851 , actually only covered the weaker statement 2\implies9, namely assumed the function to have continuous derivative. In this case, the theorem is a direct consequence of Stoke's theorem \int_{\partial D}\omega=\int_Dd\omega (also called Green's theorem when \omega is a 1-form and D is a 2-dimensional open set).
The missing step, allowing to prove 9 using only the differentiability hypothesis, was found in 1900 by Edouard Goursat . See for a thorough account of the history of this theorem.

Cauchy-Riemann equations. Equations in staments 3 and 4 are known as, respectively, the real and complex version of the Cauchy-Riemann equations. Clearly in statement 4 we are assuming that f is complex differentiable. In statement 3, though, we are not and its equivalence with statament 1 shows that the real Cauchy-Riemann equations, together with the continuity of the partial derivatives of the components of f, are equivalent to the holomorphicity of f.

Lot of efforts were put into finding the weakest possible hypotheses granting the holomorphicity of f for functions satisfying the Cauchy-Riemann equations. One of the best results in this direction is the following:
[Looman-Menchoff, 1936 ] Assume that f is continuous and that u and v have partial derivatives everywhere but for a countable set of points in \Omega and satisfy the Cauchy-Riemann equations wherever they exist. Then f is holomorphic.
Notice that the continuity assumption on f cannot be dropped:
[Looman, 1923 ]
The function
f(z) = \begin{cases}e^{-z^4},&z\neq0\cr 0,&z=0\cr\end{cases}
satisfies the Cauchy-Riemann equations at every point but it is not continuous (and so certainly not even holomorphic) at z=0.
We also remind the reader that it is essential that the derivatives of u and v exist over an open set, rather than at isolated points, as next example shows:
[Derrick, 1972 ]
The function
f(z) = \begin{cases}\frac{z^5}{|z|^4},&z\neq0\cr 0,&z=0\cr\end{cases}
is continuous everywhere and satisfies the Cauchy-Riemann equations at z=0 but it is not holomorphic at any point.
For a thorough discussion about weaker conditions granting the holomorphicity of a function, see Gray and Morris .

Morera's Theorem. A stronger version of implication 9\implies1, converse of Cauchy Theorem, was first found by Giacinto Morera in 1886 : if a continuous function f satisfies \int_\gamma fdz=0 for every loop in \Omega, then f is holomorphic. This is not equivalent to Cauchy Theorem because the condition that the integral be zero on every close loop is not necessary for the holomorphicity of the function. For instance, f(z)=1/z is holomorphic in \Bbb C\setminus\{0\} but \int_{C_0(r)} dz/z=2\pi i for every r>0.

statement.p: One method of computing all of the prime numbers less than a certain fixed positive integer N is to list all of the numbers n such that 1 \lt n \lt N. Begin by eliminating all of the multiples of 2. Next eliminate all of the multiples of 3. Now eliminate all of the multiples of 5. Notice that 4 has already been crossed out. Continue in this manner, noticing that we do not have to go all the way to N; it suffices to stop at \sqrt{N}. Using this method, compute all of the prime numbers less than N = 250. We can also use this method to find all of the integers that are relatively prime to an integer N. Simply eliminate the prime factors of N and all of their multiples. Using this method, find all of the numbers that are relatively prime to N= 120. Using the Sieve of Eratosthenes, write a program that will compute all of the primes less than an integer N.

Let {\mathbb N}^0 = {\mathbb N} \cup \{ 0 \}. Ackermann's function is the function A :{\mathbb N}^0 \times {\mathbb N}^0 \rightarrow {\mathbb N}^0 defined by the equations A(0, y) & = y + 1 A(x + 1, 0) & = A(x, 1) A(x + 1, y + 1) & = A(x, A(x + 1, y)) .

Use this definition to compute A(3, 1). Write a program to evaluate Ackermann's function. Modify the program to count the number of statements executed in the program when Ackermann's function is evaluated. How many statements are executed in the evaluation of A(4, 1)? What about A(5, 1)?

Write a computer program that will implement the Euclidean algorithm. The program should accept two positive integers a and b as input and should output \gcd( a,b) as well as integers r and s such that \gcd( a,b) = ra + sb.
